title: 107_s1035
content: The "Great Lakes Preservation Act" may be cited as the official title of this legislation. The Act includes findings related to the Great Lakes. The Great Lakes are vital public natural resources that should be protected and managed for the benefit of all. They play a crucial role in the economies of the Great Lakes States and provide safe drinking water for millions of people. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 guides the consultation process for water diversion in the region. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 outlines the process for consultation on water diversion in the region. Decision-making on Great Lakes water should be led by the Governors of the Great Lakes States to protect the basin's water and natural resources. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Administrator" refers to the head of the EPA. "Bulk fresh water" is water extracted for transportation without further processing. "From the Great Lakes basin" includes water from specific lakes, interconnecting waterways, and tributaries. The term "Great Lake" refers to Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, Lake Ontario, and Lake Superior. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec, Canada, and the term "Great Lakes State" refers to Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, or New. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec, Canada, and the term "Great Lakes State" refers to Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Wisconsin. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service. SEC. 4. MORATORIUM ON EXPORT OF BULK FRESH WATER. Bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin shall not be exported from the United States. This provision will end when an approved mechanism for water decisions is in place. Congress suggests a US-Canada agreement to uphold the moratorium. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC GREAT LAKES LIGHTHOUSES. The Great Lakes have influenced settlement, commerce, and recreation. Lighthouses in the region are historically significant but face neglect. A study will be conducted to preserve them within 3 years. The Secretary will conduct a study within 3 years to identify options for preserving lighthouses in the Great Lakes States. This study will involve reviewing National Park Service programs and consulting with various historical and preservation entities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the preservation of lighthouses in the Great Lakes States, involving various entities including historic preservation agencies and the Coast Guard.
